comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: Here is a source about Friedrich Freiherr von Georgi. "Following the outbreak of war in 1914 General Georgi immediately volunteered for a command appointment in the field but this, and later suggestions in this direction were always refused - he was too valuable at his half military-half political post as a minister."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: This looks like either a very artistic studio photograph or a photograph of a painted portrait to me. And, indeed, the URL cited by blor above shows a very similar portrait. I find myself wondering if this is a photograph from which the portrait was painted. Something doesn't feel quite the same as the portrait. www.sarahstocking.com/Biography.aspx?artistid=1967 suggests that Hermann Kosel would have been a portrait painter in Vienna, while his father, Hermann Clemens Kosel, was a portrait photographer at the right time. www.wilnitsky.com/scripts/redgallery1.dll/details?No=33034 indicates that the father was the Austrian court photographer in 1914.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: According to www.weltkriege.at/Generalitaet/02%20Generaloberst/genob.htm the three six-pointed stars on the collar are an indication of the rank of Generaloberst.

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: bior and swanq: Thanks for his full name and all the biographical information, as well as interesting clues about the relationship between painted and photographed portraits--and the men who quite possibly produced them.  We'll add  information to the description when we update.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Referencing swanq's first post, it seems likely that Hermann Clemens Kosel painted the portrait from his own photograph. The son does not seem to have been a portrait painter at this time. Biographical info: www.aeiou.at/aeiou.encyclop.k/k700778.htm;internal&ac...
